pageData.text: In this investigation, students will determine the neutralization capacity of several <button class='glossary-text'>antacids</button>. They will identify the efficacy of different antacids and determine beneficial dosages.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes 
Activity 1 : Analysis of Alka-Seltzer® - 45 minutes
Activity 2 : Analysis of Tums® or Rolaids® - 45 minutes
Activity 3 : Analysis of Milk of Magnesia - 45 minutes

pageData.text: There are many solids found in tap water that will affect your results. For this investigation, tap water should be used only for initial rinsing between trials. Purified water should be used for final rinsing and mixing solutions. Distilled water is recommended, but bottled drinking water or filtered water from a home water purifier (e.g., Brita<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or PUR<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>) may be used if distilled water is not available.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Determine the neutralization capacity of three <button class='glossary-text'>antacids.</button>
Perform an acid/base titration using multiple reactants.
Use an indicator to determine the endpoint of a reaction.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Antacids</button> are used to help alleviate the pain of <button class='glossary-text'>acid reflux</button> by neutralizing any gastrointestinal fluid that finds its way into the esophagus. Because the location of this pain is in the chest, it is commonly referred to as heartburn. Oftentimes, acid reflux occurs after specific foods are consumed, particularly food that can be more challenging to digest (i.e., raw onions) or are acidic in nature (i.e., oranges). Normally, the stomach produces hydrochloric acid to help breakdown food, but if the food proves difficult to digest the stomach responds by producing excess hydrochloric acid. Sometimes this excess acid moves backward through the digestive tract and into the esophagus, which lacks a protective lining to shield it from the corrosive nature of stomach acid.

Fatty foods are another cause of acid reflux. These foods relax the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) which separates the esophagus from the stomach. When compromised, the LES will not contain the fluids in the stomach as well as it typically does. Another cause of acid reflux is body position: when the stomach is full and you lie down, it is easier for stomach acid to backflow into the esophagus. Pregnancy, smoking, and an autoimmune disease called scleroderma are other examples of situations that can result in acid reflux.

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: A man in pain with both hands over his chest.

pageData.text: Several ailments are caused by excess acid in the stomach, including <button class='glossary-text'>acid reflux</button> and heartburn. <button class='glossary-text'>Antacids</button> are routinely prescribed to counter these conditions. An antacid is a chemical that reacts with an acid and neutralizes it, consequently leading to a neutral <button class='glossary-text'>pH</button> value. There are many over-the-counter antacids available. This investigation will determine the efficacy of three different over-the-counter antacids. The common <button class='glossary-text'>active ingredients</button> in antacids are sodium hydrogen carbonate (NaHCO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>), calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>), and magnesium hydroxide (Mg(OH)<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>). Each of these basic chemicals reacts with stomach acids using slightly different mechanisms.

The goal of this investigation is to determine the efficacy of each of these three antacids at the dosage prescribed by the manufacturer. For this investigation, 0.88 M acetic acid (vinegar, CH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>COOH) will be used as the acid. The use of this model acid enables precise testing of the antacids with minimal chemical exposure. In each of the activities, the reaction progress is monitored using <button class='glossary-text'>Bogen Universal Indicator Solution</button>. This indicator allows for the pH change of a reaction to be monitored over a wide pH range and displays a clearly visible color change when the desired <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button> is reached (Figure 1).
The equivalence point is reached when the moles of acid are equal to the moles of base in a solution. A solution is considered to be neutralized at the equivalence point.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Range of pH values between 4 and 10 in one-step increments, each corresponding to a different color produced by Bogen Universal Indicator.

options.text: to determine the efficacy of antacids

to separate out the active compounds of antacids
to determine the boiling point of antacids

hintData.body: There are many over-the-counter antacids available. This investigation will determine the efficacy of three different over-the-counter antacids. The common active ingredients in antacids are sodium hydrogen carbonate (NaHCO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>), calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>), and magnesium hydroxide (Mg(OH)<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>). Each of these basic chemicals reacts with stomach acids using slightly different mechanisms. For this investigation, 0.88 M acetic acid (vinegar, CH<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>COOH) will be used as the acid. The use of this model acid enables precise testing of the antacids with minimal chemical exposure. In each of the activities, the reaction progress is monitored using Bogen Universal Indicator Solution. This indicator allows for the pH change of a reaction to be monitored over a wide pH range and displays a clearly visible color change when the desired equivalence point is reached.

img.alt: Figure 1: Range of pH values between 4 and 10 in one-step increments, each corresponding to a different color produced by Bogen Universal Indicator.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>active ingredient</button> in Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> <button class='glossary-text'>antacid</button> is sodium hydrogen carbonate. In Activity 1, an Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet is added to acetic acid and reacts to form sodium acetate, carbon dioxide, and water as shown in the following chemical equation:
NaHCO3(aq) + CH3COOH(aq) → CH3COONa(aq)+ CO2(g)+ H2O(l)

To neutralize the acid, sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is added with a syringe. The volume of sodium hydroxide required for neutralization can be quantitatively measured, and the moles of sodium hydrogen carbonate in the Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> antacid can be determined at the <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button>. In Activity 1, the moles of acetic acid are equal to the moles of sodium hydroxide plus the moles of sodium hydrogen carbonate at the equivalence point.
Moles Acetic Acid = Moles Sodium Hydroxide + Moles Sodium Hydrogen Carbonate.

Subtracting the moles of sodium hydroxide from the moles of acetic acid in the sample solves the equation for the moles of sodium hydrogen carbonate. The moles of sodium hydrogen carbonate is then divided by the original mass of the Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet to give the neutralization capacity, which is equivalent to the moles of acid a specific mass of antacid is able to neutralize.

The procedures and calculations for Activity 2 are the same as those for Activity 1, but a Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or Rolaids<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet is substituted for the AlkaSeltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet. The <button class='glossary-text'>active ingredient</button> in Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> and Rolaids<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> <button class='glossary-text'>antacid</button> is calcium carbonate, which reacts with acetic acid to produce calcium acetate, carbon dioxide, and water as shown in the following chemical equation:
CaCO3 + 2CH3COOH(aq) → Ca(CH3COO)2(aq)+ CO2(g)+ H2O(l)

In Activity 3, milk of magnesia is tested as the antacid. The active ingredient in milk of magnesia is magnesium hydroxide, which reacts with acetic acid as shown in the following standard acid-base reaction:
Mg(OH)2(aq) + 2CH3COOH(aq) → Mg(CH3COO)2(aq)+ 2H2O(l)

Magnesium hydroxide is only slightly soluble in water. Most of the magnesium hydroxide in milk of magnesia is a solid <button class='glossary-text'>suspension</button>. A suspension is a mixture of solid particles suspended in a liquid solution. The solid particles of magnesium hydroxide settle out of the undisturbed solution over time; this is why the instructions state that the bottle must be shaken well before use. When the magnesium hydroxide suspension is mixed with acetic acid, aqueous magnesium hydroxide reacts first with the acid. As the acid-base reaction proceeds, the equilibrium between solid and aqueous magnesium hydroxide shifts due to Le Châtelier’s principle, which causes solid Mg(OH)<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> to go into solution. The procedures for testing milk of magnesia in Activity 3 differ from those used in Activities 1 and 2. In Activity 3, a quantity of milk of magnesia is weighed out, and acetic acid is used to titrate the solution to its <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button>.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between the antacid tablet titrations and the milk of magnesia titration?

options.text: The tablets are dissolved in acetic acid and titrated with sodium hydroxide; the milk of magnesia is titrated with acetic acid.
The tablets are dissolved in sodium hydroxide and titrated with acetic acid; the milk of magnesia is titrated with sodium hydroxide.
The tablets are dissolved in acetic acid, but all three antacids are titrated with sodium hydroxide.
The tablets are dissolved in sodium hydroxide, but all three antacids are titrated with acetic acid.
All three titrations are performed using the same protocol.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The antacid tablets are first dissolved in acetic acid, then the solution is titrated with sodium hydroxide. The milk of magnesia is not mixed with anything before being titrated with acetic acid.

pageData.question: Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> and Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> have active ingredients with what component in common?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The active ingredient is the component that causes the intended effects. Sodium hydrogen carbonate is the active ingredient in Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>; Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> contains calcium carbonate.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Activities 1 and 2 will test the efficacy of antacid tablets dissolved in acetic acid. To neutralize the acid, sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is added with a syringe. The volume of sodium hydroxide required for neutralization can be quantitatively measured, and the moles of active ingredient in each antacid can be determined at the equivalence point. Activity 1 will measure the sodium hydrogen carbonate in the Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> antacid. The Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or Rolaids<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> used in Activity 2 both contain calcium carbonate, which reacts with acetic acid to produce calcium acetate, carbon dioxide, and water. The active ingredient in milk of magnesia, used in Activity 3, is magnesium hydroxide, which reacts with acetic acid. The procedures for testing milk of magnesia differ from those used in Activities 1 and 2. In Activity 3, a quantity of milk of magnesia is weighed out, and acetic acid is used to titrate the solution to its equivalence point.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Activities 1 and 2 will test the efficacy of antacid tablets dissolved in acetic acid. To neutralize the acid, sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is added with a syringe. The volume of sodium hydroxide required for neutralization can be quantitatively measured, and the moles of active ingredient in each antacid can be determined at the equivalence point. Activity 1 will measure the sodium hydrogen carbonate in the Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> antacid. The Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or Rolaids<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> used in Activity 2 both contain calcium carbonate, which reacts with acetic acid to produce calcium acetate, carbon dioxide, and water. The active ingredient in milk of magnesia, used in Activity 3, is magnesium hydroxide, which reacts with acetic acid. The procedures for testing milk of magnesia differ from those used in Activities 1 and 2. In Activity 3, a quantity of milk of magnesia is weighed out, and acetic acid is used to titrate the solution to its equivalence point.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for Activity 1 and 2 in this investigation. In Activities 1 and 2, you will create an acetic acid solution to which you will add a quantity of pH indicator solution and an antacid tablet. You will then titrate the solution with sodium hydroxide until the end point is reached. Then, you will determine the volume of sodium hydroxide used in the titration. This process is repeated for a total of two trials per antacid brand. For each trial you will then calculate the moles of acetic acid titrated, the moles of sodium hydroxide used, and neutralization capacity of the tablet.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for Activity 1 and 2 in this investigation. In Activities 1 and 2, you will create an acetic acid solution to which you will add a quantity of pH indicator solution and an antacid tablet. You will then titrate the solution with sodium hydroxide until the end point is reached. Then, you will determine the volume of sodium hydroxide used in the titration. This process is repeated for a total of two trials per antacid brand. For each trial you will then calculate the moles of acetic acid titrated, the moles of sodium hydroxide used, and neutralization capacity of the tablet.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for Activity 3 in this investigation. In Activity 3, you will combine milk of magnesia and water, to which you will add a quantity of pH indicator solution. You will then titrate the mixture with acetic acid until the end point is reached. Then, you will determine the volume of acetic acid used in the titration. This process is repeated for a total of two trials. For each trial you will then calculate the moles of acetic acid used and the neutralization capacity of the antacid.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for Activity 3 in this investigation. In Activity 3, you will combine milk of magnesia and water, to which you will add a quantity of pH indicator solution. You will then titrate the mixture with acetic acid until the end point is reached. Then, you will determine the volume of acetic acid used in the titration. This process is repeated for a total of two trials. For each trial you will then calculate the moles of acetic acid used and the neutralization capacity of the antacid.

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described above.

Acetic acid and sodium hydroxide are corrosive materials. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with your skin or eyes.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: contains denatured ethyl alcohol and is a health hazard. This indicator is a potential skin, eye, and respiratory tract irritant. This indicator is toxic if ingested. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following should be at or near your workstation as you use acetic acid and sodium hydroxide in this investigation?
Which of the following safety hazards is NOT associated with the Bogen Universal Indicator Solution provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: It is extremely harmful to aquatic life.
It is a potential respiratory tract irritant.
It is a potential eye irritant.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes a solution at its equivalence point?

options.text: A neutralized solution where the moles of acid and base are equal.
An acidic solution where the moles of acid are greater than the moles of base.
An alkaline solution where the moles of base are greater than the moles of acid.
A buffered solution where the moles of acid and base are zero.
An aqueous solution where the moles of water equal those of acid and base.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items provided in your lab kit for this investigation is a suspension?

Ollie takes an antacid with calcium carbonate as its active ingredient. Based on your understanding of how calcium carbonate reacts with acid, which of the following side effects is Ollie most likely to experience?
Which of the following steps will increase the accuracy of the results of the milk of magnesia test?

options.text: Shake the bottle well before use.
Place the bottle in the refrigerator 24 hours before use.
Heat the dispensed sample in the microwave before weighing it.
Filter the sample before weighing it.
Add distilled water to the bottle before use.

assestmentData.question: In the milk of magnesia test performed in this investigation, what is the role of acetic acid?
How does Bogen Universal Indicator Solution indicate changes in the pH of a solution?

options.text: It changes the color of the solution.
It changes the temperature of solution.
It changes the solution from liquid to solid.
It produces a gas at pH values less than 7.
It produces a precipitate at pH values greater than 7.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read each activity thoroughly.
Clean the work space.
Gather all needed materials.

In Activity 1, you will dissolve an Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet in an acetic acid solution and titrate the solution using sodium hydroxide (NaOH). Two trials of this titration will be performed. You will then calculate the neutralization capacity of Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>.

pages.title: Analysis of Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> (24 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Analysis of Alka-Seltzer® (24 steps)

pageData.text: Place the large plastic cup on the weigh balance and tare the balance. Weigh approximately 5 g of acetic acid into the cup. Record the exact mass of the acetic acid in the cup in Data Table 1.
Measure 20 mL of room temperature purified water with the 50-mL graduated cylinder.
Add the 20 mL of purified water to the 5 g of acetic acid in the large cup. Gently swirl the cup to mix the solution.
Add 5–6 drops of Bogen Universal Indicator to the solution. Gently swirl the cup to mix the solution.

Place the cup on a piece of white paper, and take a photograph of the initial color of the solution. Each picture taken for this investigation should be from a point of view above the cup, looking straight down.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Weigh one tablet of Alka-Seltzer® , and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Add the weighed Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet to the solution in the cup.
Wait for the Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet to dissolve completely.
After the tablet dissolves completely, place the cup on a piece of white paper. Take a photograph of the solution in the cup.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Note: If the solution is yellow after the tablet dissolves completely, insert “0 mL” in Data Table 1 for “Volume of NaOH, total” and proceed to Step 18.
Transfer approximately 10 mL of 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to the small medicine cup. This solution will be used to fill the syringe.

Fill the 5-mL syringe with 1 M NaOH solution. Minimize the amount of air in the syringe by pointing the tip upward, gently tapping the syringe, and slowly depressing the plunger until the air is expelled. Be careful not to spill NaOH onto your hands or clothes during this procedure.
Record the initial volume of 1 M NaOH in the syringe (to the nearest 0.1 mL) in Data Table 1.

Add NaOH from the syringe in 0.1-mL increments. Gently swirl the cup between each addition. Continue adding 0.1-mL increments of 1 M NaOH until an orange color persists for a few seconds after the addition of the NaOH.
The syringe may need to be refilled during the course of each activity. Be sure to record the total volume of 1 M NaOH required to reach the <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button>.

Add 1 M NaOH dropwise from the syringe, with constant swirling, until a single drop of NaOH causes the solution to change to a yellow color that persists for a few seconds after the addition. This indicates that the endpoint of the titration has been reached and the solution is at the equivalence point.
Place the cup on the sheet of white paper, and take a photograph of the final color of the solution.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Once the equivalence point has been reached, record the final volume of 1 M NaOH in the syringe in Data Table 1.
Calculate the total volume of 1 M NaOH added to the solution. Enter this volume in Data Table 1.

Dispose of the solution in the cup. Thoroughly rinse the plastic cup with tap water at least 5 times. Then rinse the cup 3 more times with small amounts of purified water. Dry the cup completely before proceeding to Step 19.
Repeat Steps 1–18 for the second Alka-Seltzer<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet.
Before proceeding to Activity 2, dispose of the solution in the large plastic cup, rinse the cup at least 5 times with tap water, rinse 3 times with purified water, and dry the cup completely.
Calculate the moles of acetic acid used in each trial, and record the results in Data Table 1.
Volume of Acetic Acid in Liters = (Mass/Density)/1000
Moles = Volume ∗ Concentration
Calculate the moles of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) used in each trial, and record the results in Data Table 1.
Moles = (Volume/1000) ∗ Concentration
Calculate the moles of sodium hydrogen carbonate (NaHCO3) used in each trial, and record the results in Data Table 1.
Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>NaHCO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub></sub> = Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>acetic acid</sub> – Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>NaOH</sub>
Calculate the neutralization capacity of each trial, and record it in Data Table 1.
Neutralization Capacity = MolesNaHCO3/Mass of Alka-Seltzer®

In Activity 2, you will dissolve a Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or Rolaid<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet in an acetic acid solution and titrate the solution using sodium hydroxide (NaOH). Two trials of this titration will be performed. You will then calculate the neutralization capacity of the <button class='glossary-text'>antacid</button>.

pages.title: Analysis of Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or Rolaids<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> (24 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Analysis of Tums® or Rolaids® (24 steps)

pageData.text: Place the large plastic cup on the weigh balance and tare the balance. Carefully weigh 5 g of acetic acid into the cup. Record the exact mass of the acetic acid in the cup in Data Table 2.
Measure 20 mL of room temperature purified water in the 50-mL graduated cylinder.
Add the 20 mL of purified water to the 5 g of acetic acid in the large cup. Gently swirl the cup to mix the solution.
Add 5–6 drops of Bogen Universal Indicator to the solution. Gently swirl the cup to mix the solution.
Place the cup on the sheet of white paper, and take a photograph of the initial color of the solution.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Weigh one Tums® or Rolaids® tablet, and record the mass in Data Table 2.
Break the weighed tablet into smaller pieces to help it dissolve, and add it to the solution in the cup.
Gently swirl the cup for several minutes until all the pieces of the tablet are dissolved. The solution will have a milky appearance.
After the tablet dissolves completely, place the cup on the sheet of white paper, and take a photograph of the solution.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Note: If the solution is yellow after the tablet dissolves completely, insert “0 mL” in Data Table 2 for “Volume of NaOH, total” and proceed to Step 18.
Transfer approximately 10 mL of 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to the small medicine cup. This solution will be used to fill the syringe.

Fill the 5-mL syringe with 1 M NaOH solution. Minimize the amount of air in the syringe by pointing the tip upward, gently tapping the syringe, and slowly depressing the plunger until the air is expelled. Be careful not to spill NaOH onto your hands or clothes during this procedure.
Record the initial volume of 1 M NaOH in the syringe (to the nearest 0.1 mL) in Data Table 2.

Add NaOH from the syringe in 0.1-mL increments. Gently swirl the cup between each addition. Continue adding 0.1-mL increments of 1 M NaOH until an orange color persists for a few seconds after the addition of the NaOH.
The syringe may need to be refilled during the course of each activity. Be sure to record the total volume of 1 M NaOH required to reach the <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button>.

Add 1 M NaOH dropwise from the syringe, with constant swirling, until a single drop of NaOH causes the solution to change to a yellow color that persists for a few seconds after the addition. This indicates that the endpoint of the titration has been reached and the solution is at the equivalence point.
Place the cup on the sheet of white paper, and take a photograph of the final color of the solution.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Once the equivalence point has been reached, record the final volume of 1 M NaOH in the syringe in Data Table 2.
Calculate the total volume of 1 M NaOH added to the solution. Enter this volume in Data Table 2.

Dispose of the solution in the cup. Thoroughly rinse the plastic cup with tap water at least 5 times and 3 times with small amounts of purified water. Dry the cup completely before proceeding to Step 19.
Repeat Steps 1–18 for the second Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or Rolaids<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> tablet.

Before proceeding to Activity 3, dispose of the solution in the large plastic cup. Rinse the cup at least 5 times with tap water. Rinse the syringe by drawing tap water into the syringe from the large cup and expelling it at least 5 times. Rinse the cup 3 times with small amounts of purified water. With each rinse, pull up purified water from the cup into the syringe and expel it. Dry the cup completely.
Calculate the moles of acetic acid used in each trial, and record the results in Data Table 2.
Volume of Acetic Acid in Liters = (Mass/Density)/1000
Moles = Volume ∗ Concentration
Calculate the moles of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) used in each trial, and record the results in Data Table 2.
Moles = (Volume/1000) ∗ Concentration
Calculate the moles of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) used in each trial, and record the results in Data Table 2.
Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>CaCO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub></sub> = Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>acetic acid</sub> – Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>NaOH</sub>
Calculate the neutralization capacity of each trial, and record it in Data Table 2.
Neutralization Capacity = Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>CaCO<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub></sub>/Mass of Tums<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or Rolaids<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>

In Activity 3, you will titrate a sample of milk of magnesia using acetic acid. Two trials of this titration will be performed. You will then calculate the neutralization capacity of milk of magnesia.

pages.title: Analysis of Milk of Magnesia (17 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Analysis of Milk of Magnesia (17 steps)

pageData.text: Place the large plastic cup on the weigh balance and tare the balance. Shake the bottle to resuspend the solid particles of magnesium hydroxide. Weigh 2.5 g of milk of magnesia into the cup. Record the exact mass in Data Table 3.
Measure 20 mL of room temperature purified water in the 50-mL graduated cylinder.
Add the 20 mL of purified water to the 2.5 g of milk of magnesia in the cup. Gently swirl the cup to mix the solution.
Add 5–6 drops of Bogen Universal Indicator to the solution in the cup. Gently swirl the cup to mix the solution.
Place the cup on the sheet of white paper, and take a photograph of the initial color of the solution.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Transfer approximately 10 mL of acetic acid to the small medicine cup. This solution will be used to fill the syringe.
Fill the syringe with the acetic acid. Minimize the amount of air in the syringe using the procedure in Activity 1, Step 11.
Record the initial volume of acetic acid in the syringe (to the nearest 0.1 mL) in Data Table 3.

Add acetic acid in 0.5-mL increments from the syringe to the solution in the cup. Gently swirl the cup between each addition to mix. Continue adding 0.5-mL increments of acetic acid until the solution changes to a green color that persists for at least 10 seconds.

Add acetic acid dropwise from the syringe, with constant swirling, until a single drop of acetic acid causes the solution to change to a yellow color that persists for a few seconds. At this point, the solution should be transparent. These two properties indicate that the <button class='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button> has been reached.
Once the equivalence point has been reached, record the final volume of acetic acid remaining in the syringe in Data Table 3.
Calculate the total volume of acetic acid added to the solution. Enter this volume in Data Table 3.
Place the cup on the sheet of white paper, and take a photograph of the final color of the solution.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Dispose of the solution in the cup. Thoroughly rinse the plastic cup with tap water at least 5 times. Then rinse 3 times with small amounts of purified water. Dry the cup completely before proceeding to Step 15.
Repeat Steps 1–13 using a second sample of milk of magnesia.
Calculate the moles of acetic acid used in each trial, and record the results in Data Table 3.
Volume of Acetic Acid in Liters = (Mass/Density)/1000
Moles = Volume ∗ Concentration
Calculate the neutralization capacity of each trial, and record it in Data Table 3.
Neutralization Capacity = Moles<sub class='bodySubscript'>acetic acid</sub> / Mass of Milk of Magnesia

text: Dispose of all solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for several minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.title: Questions
text: Which antacid is the most effective (has the highest number of moles of active ingredient) per gram of antacid? Which antacid is the most effective based on the manufacturer’s recommended dosage?
Milk of magnesia is generally not used as an antacid, even though it has strong antacid properties. Why might this be the case?
Why do you think the milk of magnesia takes longer to stabilize the pH during the titration than Alka-Seltzer or Tums?

pageData.content: Figure 1. Bogen Universal Indicator color chart
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Range of pH values between 4 and 10 in one-step increments, each corresponding to a different color produced by Bogen Universal Indicator.

This map describes the workflow for Activity 1 and 2 in this investigation. In Activities 1 and 2, you will create an acetic acid solution to which you will add a quantity of pH indicator solution and an antacid tablet. You will then titrate the solution with sodium hydroxide until the end point is reached. Then, you will determine the volume of sodium hydroxide used in the titration. This process is repeated for a total of two trials per antacid brand. For each trial you will then calculate the moles of acetic acid tit,rated, the moles of sodium hydroxide used, and neutralization capacity of the tablet.

This map describes the workflow for Activity 3 in this investigation. In Activity 3, you will combine milk of magnesia and water, to which you will add a quantity of pH indicator solution. You will then titrate the mixture with acetic acid until the end point is reached. Then, you will determine the volume of acetic acid used in the titration. This process is repeated for a total of two trials. For each trial you will then calculate the moles of acetic acid used and the neutralization capacity of the antacid.

data.title: Acid reflux
data.content: Acidic gastric fluids flow backward into the esophagus, heartburn

data.title: Active ingredient
data.content: The component that causes the intended effects

data.title: Antacid
data.content: A chemical that reacts with an acid and neutralizes it, consequently leading to a neutral pH value

data.title: Bogen Universal Indicator Solution
data.content: Allows for the pH change of a reaction to be monitored over a wide pH range and displays a clearly visible color change when the desired equivalence point is reached

data.title: Equivalence point
data.content: Reached when the moles of acid are equal to the moles of base in a solution, neutralize

data.title: pH
data.content: The acidity or alkalinity of a solution on a logarithmic scale ,7 is neutral, below 7 is acidic, above 7 is basic

data.title: Suspension
data.content: A mixture of solid particles suspended in a liquid solution
